item.title: Leetcode 24: Swap Nodes in Pairs
item.description: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€é“leetcodeä¸­ç­‰éš¾åº¦çš„é¢˜ç›®ã€‚é¢˜ç›®æè¿°å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š è¿™é¢˜è™½ç„¶æ ‡çš„æ˜¯mediumï¼Œå…¶å®žæ€è·¯éžå¸¸çš„ç®€å•ï¼Œä¸è¿‡å®žçŽ°èµ·æ¥ç¨å¾®æœ‰ä¸€ç‚¹trickyã€‚ å¯¹æ¯ä¸¤ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹è¿›è¡Œpair-wiseäº¤æ¢ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªtemp pointer æŒ‡å‘ç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªnodeï¼Œäº¤æ¢å‰ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼Œå†ä»Žç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªnodeâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
è¿™æ˜¯ä¸€é“leetcodeä¸­ç­‰éš¾åº¦çš„é¢˜ç›®ã€‚é¢˜ç›®æè¿°å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

è¿™é¢˜è™½ç„¶æ ‡çš„æ˜¯mediumï¼Œå…¶å®žæ€è·¯éžå¸¸çš„ç®€å•ï¼Œä¸è¿‡å®žçŽ°èµ·æ¥ç¨å¾®æœ‰ä¸€ç‚¹trickyã€‚ å¯¹æ¯ä¸¤ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹è¿›è¡Œpair-wiseäº¤æ¢ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªtemp pointer æŒ‡å‘ç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªnodeï¼Œäº¤æ¢å‰ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼Œå†ä»Žç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªnodeå¼€å§‹å³å¯ã€‚

æ­¤é¢˜å¾ˆæ˜¾ç„¶å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨iterativeä¸Žrecursiveä¸¤ç§æ–¹æ³•æ¥è§£é¢˜ã€‚

Iterative

å…ˆæ¥çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹iterativeçš„åšæ³•ï¼š

/**
 * Definition for singly-linked list.
 * type ListNode struct {
 *     Val int
 *     Next *ListNode
 * }
 */
func swapPairs(head *ListNode) *ListNode {
    if head == nil || head.Next == nil {
        return head
    }
    dummy := new(ListNode)
    previous := new(ListNode)
    dummy = previous
    previous.Next = head
    for previous.Next != nil && previous.Next.Next != nil {
        a := previous.Next
        b := a.Next
        previous.Next, b.Next, a.Next = b, a, b.Next
        previous = a
    }
    return dummy.Next
}

çœ‹ä¸ŠåŽ»å¾ˆç®€å•çš„é€»è¾‘å…¶å®žæš—è—å¾ˆå¤šçŽ„æœºã€‚

  1. é¦–å…ˆåœ¨ç¬¬2è¡Œcheckæœ€æ˜Žæ˜¾çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªè¾¹ç•Œæ¡ä»¶ï¼š headå’Œhead.Nextæ˜¯å¦ä¸ºnilã€‚
  2. å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªdummy nodeæ¥ä¿å­˜åŽŸå§‹çš„head pointerã€‚
  3. è¿™é‡Œå†å»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªprevious nodeæ¥ä¿å­˜ä¸Šä¸€æ¬¡äº¤æ¢åŽçš„ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªnodeã€‚åŽŸå› åœ¨äºŽï¼Œäº¤æ¢ä¸¤ä¸ªnodeä¹‹åŽ éœ€è¦æ›´æ–°ä¹‹å‰ä¸€æ¬¡äº¤æ¢åŽç¬¬äºŒä¸ªnodeçš„Next pointerã€‚
  4. è¿™é‡Œæœ€éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ç¬¬12è¡Œã€‚è¿™é‡Œç”¨åˆ°äº†Goè¯­è¨€ç±»ä¼¼äºŽPython swap valuesçš„ä¸€ä¸ªåŠŸèƒ½æ¥ç›´æŽ¥åŒæ—¶ æ”¹å˜ä¸‰ä¸ªå˜é‡çš„valuesã€‚å¦‚æžœè¿™ä¸€è¡Œæœ‰å›°éš¾ç†è§£çš„è¯ï¼Œ ä¸€ä¸ªæ¯”è¾ƒæœ‰ç”¨çš„Stack Overflowå›žç­”å¯ä»¥åœ¨è¿™é‡Œæ‰¾åˆ°ã€‚

è¿™é¢˜çš„runtime complexityä¸ºO(N)ã€‚

Recursive

çœ‹å®Œiterativeè§£æ³•ä»¥åŽï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å†æ¥çœ‹ä¸€ä¸‹recursiveçš„è§£æ³•ã€‚

func swapPairs(head *ListNode) *ListNode {
    if head == nil || head.Next == nil {
        return head
    }
    first, second, third := head, head.Next, head.Next.Next
    second.Next = first
    first.Next = swapPairs(third)
    
    return second;
}

ä½¿ç”¨é€’å½’çš„è§£æ³•çœ‹ä¸ŠåŽ»å°±ç®€å•æ˜“æ‡‚äº†å¾ˆå¤šã€‚

item.content:encoded:
JavaScript Type: Strings

String in JavaScript are sequences of Unicode characters. ä»¥ä¸‹variable declarationåœ¨JSä¸­æ˜¯validçš„ï¼š

const ä½ å¥½  = 'hello';
console.log(ä½ å¥½); // hello

JSä¸­æ²¡æœ‰dedicated char type, å¦‚æžœéœ€è¦è¡¨ç¤ºcharçš„è¯ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬ç”¨stringæ¥ä»£æ›¿ã€‚Stringæœ‰length propertyï¼š

'hello'.length; // 5

Stringå±žäºŽObjectï¼Œå¯ä»¥å¯¹Stringåšç±»ä¼¼äºŽä»¥ä¸‹çš„operationsï¼š

'hello'.charAt(0); // "h"
'hello, world'.replace('world', 'mars'); // "hello, mars"
'hello'.toUpperCase(); // "HELLO"

JavaScript: Other Types

JS distinguishes between null and undefined. null specifically stands for non-value, whereas undefined stands for uninitialized value. 

const a = [1, 2, 3, 4];
a[5]; // undefined
a[5] = null; 
a; // [1, 2, 3, 4, undefined, null];

JSæ”¯æŒBoolean Typeï¼Œå…·ä½“å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

  1. false, 0, empty string "", NaN, nullä»¥åŠundefinedéƒ½ä¼šè¢«è§†ä½œfalseã€‚

  2. ä»¥ä¸Šä¹‹å¤–çš„valueéƒ½ä¼šè¢«è§†ä½œtrueã€‚

    Boolean(''); // false
Boolean(234); // true

Variables

JSæœ‰ä¸‰ç§declare variableçš„æ–¹å¼ï¼Œnamely var, letå’Œconstã€‚ letä¼šdeclare block-level variableã€‚

// myLetVariable is *not* visible out here

for (let myLetVariable = 0; myLetVariable < 5; myLetVariable++) {
  // myLetVariable is only visible in here
}

// myLetVariable is *not* visible out here

åŒæ ·çš„ï¼Œconstä¹Ÿä¼šdeclare block-level variableï¼Œä½†ä¸Žletçš„åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºŽconstdeclareçš„variableä¸å¯ä»¥re-assign valueã€‚

const foo = 'bar';
foo = 'hello'; // will throw an error

varåœ¨ES6 standardä¸­å·²ç»å¾ˆå°‘è¢«ä½¿ç”¨äº†ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå®ƒä¼šautomatically declares a global variableã€‚ Traditionally, var is the only way to declare a variable in JS. 

// myVarVariable *is* visible out here 

for (var myVarVariable = 0; myVarVariable < 5; myVarVariable++) { 
  // myVarVariable is visible to the whole function 
} 

// myVarVariable *is* visible out here

Note:

  • If you declare a variable without assigning its value, it will be undefined initially.
  • åœ¨ES6ä¹‹å‰ï¼ŒJSæ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰block-level scopeçš„ï¼Œåªæœ‰functionå­˜åœ¨scopeï¼Œè¿™ä¸€ç‚¹å’ŒJavaç­‰è¯­è¨€æ˜¯æœ‰åŒºåˆ«çš„ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼ŒES6æ–°å¢žçš„letå’Œconstå…è®¸declare block-scoped variablesã€‚

Operators

JSæ”¯æŒåŸºæœ¬çš„operatorsï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬+, -, *, /ä»¥åŠ%ã€‚

x += 5;
x = x + 5; // equivalent to above
x++; // ++ and -- can be used

+ operator will do string concatenation:

'hello' + ' world!'; // hello world!

If you add a string to a number, they will be converted into string first:

'3' + 4 + 5; // '345'
3 + 4 + '5'; // '75'

Comparisons in JS is a bit interesting. Double equal sign will perform type coersion if you give different types:

123 == '123'; // true
1 == true; // true
// To avoid coersion, use triple-equal sign
123 === '123'; // false
1 === true; // false

JS also supports bit-wise operations.

  • & (bitwise AND)
  • | (bitwise OR)
  • ^ (bitwise XOR)
  • ~ (bitwise NOT)
  • << (left shift)
  • >> (arithmetic right shift)
  • >>> (logical right shift) Different from C, logical right shift can be done by the >>> operator.

JavaScript Building Blocks: Types

  • Number

  • Number
  • String

  • Symbol

  • Object

    • Function
    • Array

  • null

Numbers

JavaScriptæ˜¯ä¸æ”¯æŒçº¯æ‰€è°“Integerçš„ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´Number Typeå°±æ˜¯floating pointã€‚ JavaScriptä½¿ç”¨IEEE754 double precision (64-bits) floating pointã€‚ JavaScriptæ”¯æŒä¸€ä¸ªbuilt-inçš„Objectä¸ºMathï¼Œä½¿ç”¨è€…å¯ä»¥ç”¨å…¶è¿›è¡Œä¸€äº›æ•°å­¦è¿ç®—ã€‚

Math.sin(3.5);
const circumference = 2 * Math.PI * r;

JSæ”¯æŒä½¿ç”¨parseIntæ¥å°†Stringè½¬æ¢ä¸ºNumberã€‚Function takes an optional second argument as the base of the string representation:

parseInt('123', 10); // 123
parseInt('010', 10); // 10
parseInt('11', 2); // 3

There is a function called parseFloat which behaves similarly with parseInt but doesnâ€™t take a second argument. Instead, it always assumes base 10 representations. An unary + sign can be used to convert string into numbers as well:

+ '42'; // 42
+ `010`; // 10
+ `0x10`; // 16

A special value called NaN (which stands for â€œNot a Numberâ€) is used in JS:

parseInt('foo', 10); // NaN

Any mathematical operation operating on NaN will also return NaN (which is quite toxicâ€¦):

NaN + 5; // NaN

One can use the built-in function isNaN to test whether a value is NaN or not:

isNaN(NaN); // true

JS also supports two Infinity values:

1 / 0; Infinity
-1 / 0; -Infinity

One can also test whether a value is infinity of not by using the isFinite function:

isFinite(1 / 0); // false
isFinite(-Infinity); // false
isFinite(NaN); // false

One thing to point out for comparing the difference between + and parseInt,parseFloat is that, two parse functions will terminate once they hit invalid characters and return the value up to that point, whereas the + operand will simply return NaN if a invalid argument is given:

+ '10.2abc'; // NaN
parseInt('10.2abc', 10); // 10
parseFloat('10.2abc'); // 10.2
